title: A Visual Guide to the Aztec Pantheon
introduction: Can you imagine Rio de Janeiro without the BRT, the VLT, the Porto Maravilha, the Museum of Tomorrow, the Museum of Art of Rio, the Rio Operations Center  (COR), the Transoeste, the Transcarioca, and the Transolímpica? Well, without the 2016 Olympic and Paralympic Games, none of this would have become a reality.

The hosting of the Games was crucial in making various urban facilities that now positively impact the lives of Cariocas a reality, many of which might never have materialized without the impetus provided by the event.

Since the project's inception, the Rio City Hall has aimed to ensure a great legacy for the city and its residents. The preparation for the event was used to accelerate long-awaited changes, which brought significant improvements to the quality of life for Cariocas.

The Olympics and Paralympics represented a milestone in the city's recent history. In addition to putting Rio in the global spotlight, the Games paved the way for significant transformations in infrastructure, services, transportation, and education.
In this special report, we invite you to revisit or discover the Olympic legacy that has transformed — and continues to transform — our Rio de Janeiro.
introductionone: In addition to planning and building facilities to guarantee the improvement of the quality of life of cariocas, Rio's Olympic project adopted nomadic architecture in several arenas. This meant that after the Games, these facilities would have new uses for the population.

This construction concept foresees the reuse of sports facilities to transform them into other public facilities, including in other areas of the city. This is the case of the Future Arena, which hosted Olympic handball and Paralympic goalball. After the end of the competitions, its structure was used to build four schools in the GET (Educational Technological Gymnasium) model, with the capacity to serve 1,700 students.
All four units are located in the West Zone of the city (Santa Cruz, Bangu, Campo Grande, and Rio das Pedras), where other important facilities were built and are now part of the Olympic legacy.
introductiontwo: In addition to the aforementioned facilities, many other projects are part of the legacy that are not directly related to the sporting event but took advantage of the Olympic opportunity to become a reality. These were infrastructure works, mainly related to mobility and urbanization, which were made feasible or accelerated because Rio became the host city of the Games.

One of the most significant transformations refers to the expansion of the high-capacity transportation network. The efforts of the Rio City Hall aimed to create a new model of urban mobility in which the city was completely interconnected, facilitating and speeding up displacements and breaking old geographical and social barriers.

To achieve this, investments were made in projects such as the Transoeste, Transcarioca, and Transolímpica BRT lines, the VLT, and more recently, the Gentileza Terminal. These works boosted transportation in the city, reducing distances and improving the quality of life for thousands of cariocas, especially in the North and West zones.
Next, you will learn more about the Olympic Legacy mobility projects that have expedited and facilitated how cariocas get around Rio.
introductionthree: In the next phase of the Rio de Janeiro City Hall's ongoing commitment to preserving and remembering the Olympic legacy, totems, plaques, and seals will be installed in various spaces and buildings throughout the city.

By identifying and celebrating the places that were transformed or benefited by the Games, we are strengthening the sense of community and belonging, while promoting tourism and awareness of the event's importance for our present and future.
introductionfour: Explore all the equipment and works done due to the Olympic and Paralympic Games in the city of Rio in the tool below:
source_tlalte_label: Colorized detail from a stone sculpture exhibited at the Templo Mayor museum

tlalte-steps.description: This is the map of the Olympic Legacy in Rio de Janeiro. We will start our tour in the central region of the city, the historical cradle of Rio de Janeiro. In addition to investments in conservation, this entire area has undergone a process of urban renewal, with the revitalization of the Port area and the recovery of the Downtown.

tlalte-steps.title: COR
tlalte-steps.description: The Rio Operations Center (COR) was the first Olympic facility delivered by the Rio de Janeiro City Hall to the cariocas. Inaugurated in December 2010, its legacy remains 24 hours a day, seven days a week. COR monitors and integrates Rio de Janeiro in essential areas: urban mobility and weather. With the integration of 50 public agencies and the use of more than 3,500 cameras, COR monitors the daily life of Rio in areas essential for the city's functioning, such as urban mobility and meteorology, always with the goal of anticipating solutions and minimizing the impact of occurrences.

tlalte-steps.title: Praça Mauá (Porto Maravilha)
tlalte-steps.description: Built in the early 20th century, the historic Praça Mauá was reopened in September 2015, after being revitalized as part of the Porto Maravilha project. With green areas, two new cultural spaces - MAR and the Museum of Tomorrow - and without the Perimetral Overpass that blocked the view of Guanabara Bay, the square has become a meeting point and social integration not only for the city but for the entire Metropolitan Region. The new Praça Mauá has become one of the main symbols of Porto Maravilha, an urban requalification program for an area of 5 million square meters launched in 2009, as part of Rio's preparation for the 2016 Games.

tlalte-steps.title: Museum Of Tomorrow
tlalte-steps.description: An icon of the city's port area, the Museum of Tomorrow is also a legacy of the Games. Inaugurated in 2015, it was part of the urban revitalization project of Porto Maravilha. With futuristic architecture, it is an interactive science museum that uses innovation to bring reflections on technology, sustainability, and the future.

tlalte-steps.title: Museu de Arte do Rio
tlalte-steps.description: Inaugurated in 2013, the Museu de Arte do Rio, MAR, is a cultural institution that preserves and promotes the art and history of the city. Located next to the Museum of Tomorrow in Praça Mauá and also part of the Porto Maravilha project, MAR is another cultural option that the city gained due to the Games, attracting residents and tourists.

tezca-steps.description: Now, let's go to the West Zone of the city, to get to know the GETs and other works that exist thanks to the 2016 Olympic and Paralympic Games.

tezca-steps.title: Rita Lee Park
tezca-steps.description: Formerly the Olympic Boulevard, which during the Games connected all areas of the Olympic Park and was used by athletes and spectators, Rita Lee Park is a public space spanning 36,000 square meters, offering various sports and leisure options for the population. It comprises a grove with over 900 trees and 16,000 shrubs, sports courts, squares, a skate park, children's playgrounds, and fitness equipment. The new park, which pays tribute to the queen of Brazilian rock, is located in a space that interconnects the entire Olympic Park, including the arenas, terraces, and the “Live Site”, an esplanade for events in front of Jacarepaguá Lagoon.

tezca-steps.title: GEO Isabel Salgado
tezca-steps.description: Rio de Janeiro made history by transforming an Olympic stadium into a public school for the first time. Located in the Olympic Park in Barra da Tijuca, Carioca Arena 3, which hosted taekwondo and fencing competitions during the Olympics and judo during the Paralympics, was converted into the largest municipal school. The Isabel Salgado Olympic Educational Gymnasium (GEO) was named in honor of one of the greatest names in world volleyball and an Olympic athlete. The school serves approximately one thousand students from first to ninth grade in full-time education and consists of 24 classrooms, a multi-purpose room, a pedagogical support room, a cafeteria, a kitchen, dressing rooms, and bathrooms. Additionally, it has two sports courts and areas for judo, martial arts, table tennis, and gymnastics.

tezca-steps.title: GETs
tezca-steps.description: GET is the most innovative school model in the country, based on the STEAM method (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics), which integrates various areas of knowledge to stimulate creativity, critical thinking, and human sensitivity, offering full-time education. The Rio de Janeiro City Hall has already inaugurated over 100 GETs, four of which are Olympic legacies. As part of the Rio 2016 Games Legacy Plan, the Future Arena was dismantled at the end of the competitions and transformed into four schools, with a capacity for 1,700 students. All units are located in neighborhoods in the West Zone: GET Emiliano Galdino in Santa Cruz, GET José Mauro de Vasconcelos in Bangu, GET Nelcy Noronha in Campo Grande, and GET Mestre Diego Braga in Rio das Pedras.

tezca-steps.title: Deodoro Radical Park
tezca-steps.description: Deodoro Radical Park, located in one of the most deprived areas of the West Zone, bordering the Baixada Fluminense, offers activities for residents of the region. With 500,000 square meters, it is one of the largest leisure areas in Rio de Janeiro and has several options for those who want to practice sports or simply enjoy a day in the sun by the pool. Part of the former Deodoro Sports Complex, where competitions in different modalities took place in 2016, such as the Canoe Slalom, it is another facility that only exists thanks to the Rio Olympic and Paralympic Games.

tezca2-steps.title: BRT
tezca2-steps.description: One of the most important and transformative projects for mobility in the city, the Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) system began to be built and implemented for the Rio 2016 Games. With exclusive lanes and modern articulated buses, it provided faster and more efficient travel for Rio residents, integrating the most distant areas and improving the quality of life for users, especially those in the North and West zones. Currently, Rio has four BRT corridors totaling 150 km: Transoeste (inaugurated in 2012), Transcarioca (2014), Transolímpica (2016), and Transbrasil (2024).

tezca2-steps.title: transoeste
tezca2-steps.description: The first BRT to be delivered as an early legacy of the Rio Games was Transoeste, in 2012, connecting Barra da Tijuca to Campo Grande, Paciência, and Santa Cruz. The corridor includes the Grota Funda Tunnel, which was the first in the city to cut through the Pedra Branca Massif, contributing to the end of the West Zone's road isolation. Transoeste provided faster and more comfortable trips for Rio residents in this region, promoting urban integration and facilitating access to services and jobs.

tezca2-steps.title: transcarioca
tezca2-steps.description: Inaugurated in June 2014, before the start of the World Cup, Transcarioca was the second BRT corridor to begin operating in Rio. It connects Barra da Tijuca to Tom Jobim Airport on Governador Island, crossing the densely populated Rio suburbs. The corridor passes through 27 neighborhoods in the North and West zones, including four of Rio's largest favela complexes: Cidade de Deus and the Alemão, Penha, and Maré complexes. Transcarioca facilitated the commutes of residents in the region, shortening distances and reducing travel time. Additionally, it stimulated economic and social development along its route.

tezca2-steps.title: transolimpica
tezca2-steps.description: The main link between the Barra Olympic Park and the Deodoro Sports Complex during the 2016 Games, Transolímpica was the third BRT corridor to be inaugurated. By connecting Recreio dos Bandeirantes and Barra da Tijuca to Deodoro, it provided the population with interconnection between neighborhoods in the West Zone up to Avenida Brasil. In addition to exclusive lanes for articulated buses, the project also created an expressway for automobiles and opened up new routes in the Pedra Branca Massif, with the construction of two double tunnels.

tezca2-steps.title: vlt
tezca2-steps.description: In the mobility area, Rio's downtown area gained the Light Rail Vehicle (VLT) just before the Rio 2016 Games. The electric tram system integrates with all means of transportation in the downtown and port area: ferries, metro, train, bus, Novo Rio Bus Station, Santos Dumont Airport, Providência cable car, cruise terminal, and, most recently, the Gentileza Terminal and Transbrasil BRT. Currently, there are four VLT lines in operation, totaling 29 stops and stations.

tezca2-steps.title: Gentileza Terminal
tezca2-steps.description: Opened in 2024, eight years after the Games, the Gentileza Intermodal Terminal (TIG), the country's most modern transport integration hub, is also an Olympic legacy. Within the concept of nomadic architecture, it was built from the metal structures of the IBC, the International Broadcasting Center that was located in the Olympic Park and was responsible for generating and distributing images of the Games worldwide. Located in front of the Novo Rio Bus Station, the TIG connects the services of Transbrasil BRT, two VLT lines, and 14 regular municipal bus lines, as well as an express service to Tom Jobim International Airport. The Gentileza Terminal integrates some of the modes that are part of the city's new transportation system that began to be implemented due to the Olympics, such as BRT and VLT. Additionally, it is located in the Porto Maravilha region, another symbol of transformation from the Rio 2016 Games.

pantheon.text: Death groups all the gods related to destructive forces, whether they come from nature or humankind, like the underworld, war or natural disasters.
Life, like death, combines both renewal of nature and the continuation of the human species and, thus, includes fertility, birth, food or even cosmic creation.
Spiritual can be gods related to human intellectual interests, like art, lust and excess, or gods related to metaphysical interests, like the mysteries of nature, its creation and its purpose.
Material deities offer protection to the activities that ensure the survival of Aztec civilization, from trading and craft to war or food.
But, as we’ve seen with Tlaltecuhtli and Tezcatlipoca, Aztec Gods rarely fit into a single category, and most are both creative and destructive, spiritual and material, especially the 13 major Gods.

Explore each illustration to see if you can spot the attributes that align with the Gods’ domains. Be sure to seek out the 13 major Gods, where you can also learn about Aztec society’s lasting legacy, from modern election practices in the south of Mexico to the foods eaten around the world.
You can start exploring with Ometeotl, a major figure often deemed as the primordial God, as he is the cosmic energy that gives life to everything.

main_gods.name: Ometeotl
main_gods.title: The matrix of all things
main_gods.minibio: Androgynous entity, Ometeotl is responsible for the creation of the gods and the world, on the back of Cipactli, but stays distant from mankind.

sources_group.title: Reshaping the world: debates on Mesoamerican cosmologies
sources_group.author: Ana Maria Diaz Alvarez

sources_group.title: Ometeotl and the Emergence of the Male-Female Polarity in Aztec Cosmogony
sources_group.author: Sylvie Peperstraete

sources_group.title: Ometeotl, the God that Didn’t Exist

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: The only symbol of truth and permanence for Aztecs is Ometeotl, the cosmic energy which gives life to everything, and structures it, like a fabric upon which gods and humans weave their history. Ometeotl doesn’t seem to be worshiped, besides mentions by some poets. However, they’re the core of the Aztec worldview. Like the cell’s mitosis, Ometeotl divides themself into Ometecuhtli (male) and Omecihuatl (female), then into the four creation gods. So every Aztec god is a specific disguise or embodiment of Ometeotl.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: This deity is still celebrated annually in Morelos at the Ometeotl festival, which showcases the diversity of Mexican culture. But Ometeotl’s legacy can also be seen in the rise of the philosophical notion of complexity and complex systems. The Aztec’s pantheon is indeed a perfect example of it, where all the parts interact with each other in various ways, culminating in a higher order.

main_gods.name: Huitzilopochtli
main_gods.title: The emperor god
main_gods.minibio: God of war, thunderstorms, fire and sun. He’s the original deity of the nomadic tribe of Mexica, also known as Aztecs. He was a warrior who needed blood to win his battle against darkness.

sources_group.title: Incarnations of the Aztec Supernatural: The Image of Huitzilopochtli in Mexico and Europe
sources_group.author: Elizabeth H. Boone

sources_group.title: Huitzilopochtli: The History of the Aztec God of War and Human Sacrifice
sources_group.author: Ernesto Novato

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Huitzilopochtli is the protector of Aztec people through their journey from the mythic city of Aztlan (potentially the north of Mexico) to Texcoco Lake, where they built Tenochtitlan. Struggling to feed the fifth sun (Tonatiuh) and thus allowing the whole world to exist, Aztecs helped him thanks to wars, conquests and captives. While their blood is spilled to the ground to feed the earth, their heart is offered to the sun. Once again, death brings life.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: The presence of Huitzilopochtli is still obvious today. Look no further than Mexico’s flag. At the center of it, an eagle eats a snake on a cactus. The same that Mexica saw upon their arrival at Texcoco. But, mainly, Huitzilopochtli's shadow still lies over the political landscape. The Empire his followers built (one which roughly restructured the countryside and created a sense of unity, despite the variety of local cultures) reshaped Mexican history well into the present.

main_gods.name: Quetzalcoatl
main_gods.title: The civilizing god
main_gods.minibio: One of the main divinities worshiped in Mesoamerica. He's the god of agriculture, arts, love science and wind. Exiled by his brother Tezcatlipoca, his expected return has been seen, at first, as the arrival of Hernan Cortez in 1519.

sources_group.title: Quetzalcoatl, in myth, archeology, and art
sources_group.author: Demetrio Sodi, José López Portillo and Fernando Díaz Infante

sources_group.title: The Myth of Quetzalcoatl: Religion, Rulership, and History in the Nahua World
sources_group.author: Alfredo López Austin

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: K’iche’, Mayan or Toltecs: The feathered serpent figure has been revered for centuries in Mesoamerica. Although he’s a major fertility god for Aztecs, he also birthed a sweeter life for humans by giving them agriculture, science, arts, game, medicine and drugs, and especially love.

All those gifts remain in Mexican culture, thanks to historical and archeological work, but the most vivacious one remains the Náhuatl language. Spoken since the 7th century, today it’s the second most common language in the country, with around 2M speakers, mostly in rural areas.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: Contemporary Náhuatl is not the same as the original, as it has been Latinized and standardized since the Spanish Conquest, not to mention the fragmentation of Náhuatl into a multitude of local variations, and the urban migration, which weakens its transmission. Local dialects became, in the early 1990s, a strong symbol for the recognition of indigenous rights. And, finally, in 2003, they were recognized as co-official national languages by the government.

main_gods.name: Tezcatlipoca
main_gods.title: The trickster
main_gods.minibio: Omnipotent god of rulers, sorcerers or warriors, he rules night, death, discord, conflict, temptation, change and destruction. Symbolized by the jaguar, he's a rival of Quetzalcoatl and one of the most complex Aztec gods.

sources_group.title: A Guide to Mexican Witchcraft
sources_group.author: William Madsen, Claudia Madsen Mariana Yampolsky

sources_group.title: Symbolizing Tezcatlipoca
sources_group.author: Nicholas J. Saunders and Elizabeth Baquedano

sources_group.title: Le nahualli : homme-dieu et double animal au Mexique
sources_group.author: Roberto Martinez Gonzalez

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Despite witch hunts during the Spanish Conquest, magic has survived into the present, with brujos/brujas or curanderos/curanderas, especially in the south of Mexico Valley, Tuxtla (Chiapas) or in Catemaco, a village near Vera Cruz, where politicians still come to seek mystical help before elections.
content.name: Mayahuel
content.title: Goddess of pulque
content.minibio: Goddess of the maguay plant and all its by-products, especially pulque. Said to have 400 breasts to nurture her children, she gave love to mankind with her romance with Quetzalcoatl.

sources_group.title: The Children of Mayahuel: Agaves, Human Cultures, and Desert Landscapes in Northern Mexico
sources_group.author: Cynthia Radding

sources_group.title: Mayáhuel: Mesoamerican deities of the maguey, as depicted in the C​odex Borgia
sources_group.author: Richard Guzman

sources_group.title: Pulque and the four hundred divine yet helplessly drunken rabbits
sources_group.author: Zoe Saadia

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Pulque (a mild alcoholic beverage made from maguey) is quite a paradoxical element of Aztec culture. Whereas their pantheon counted hundreds of gods related to it, all children of Mayahuel, it was restricted to very few humans (warriors, sacrificial victims, priests and nobles for celebrations, or older people and pregnant women) and public drunkenness was severely punished.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: Maguey plantations brought wealth to powerful families in Mexico during the 19th century, but pulque represents only 10% of the alcoholic beverages consumed in Mexico. However, a modern version of it, thanks to the European distillation technique, became very popular worldwide: tequila. Additionally, maguey, with its low water consumption, is actually a point of interest for agronomists and could help to solve some water problems in Mexico.

cta_wip: We have, so far, in our database around 137 gods. And another batch is in the “work in progress” phase, as we still lack information, iconographic resources or simply the time to render them in graphic vector.
We hope to improve and expand it in the future so, if you’re interested in this project, you can contact me for corrections in written or iconographic resources. Thank you in advance for your help!
